sub_topic: Lorentz transformation of coordinates and time
message_1: A spacecraft is traveling at 0.6c (relative to Earth) towards a planet located 10 light-years away. According to the spacecraft's clock, the journey has taken 12 years. Calculate the time elapsed on Earth during the journey, taking into account the effects of time dilation predicted by Lorentz transformation of coordinates and time.
message_2:
To calculate the time elapsed on Earth during the journey, we need to consider the time dilation effect predicted by the special theory of relativity. The time dilation formula is given by:

Δt = Δt0 / √(1 - v^2/c^2)

where Δt is the time elapsed on Earth (also known as the dilated time), Δt0 is the proper time (time elapsed according to the spacecraft's clock), v is the relative velocity of the spacecraft, and c is the speed of light.

In this problem, we are given:

Δt0 = 12 years
v = 0.6c

We can now plug these values into the time dilation formula:

Δt = 12 years / √(1 - (0.6c)^2/c^2)

Δt = 12 years / √(1 - 0.36)

Δt = 12 years / √(0.64)

Δt = 12 years / 0.8

Δt ≈ 15 years

So, the time elapsed on Earth during the journey is approximately 15 years.
